nodes.text: IoT-enabled devices and architectures can improve home automation by enabling remote, sensor-driven control and monitoring of domestic appliances
Definition: The Internet of Things (IoT) extends the internet to connect appliances equipped with sensors, enabling automated device-to-device and remote interactions
IoT-based home automation provides multiple benefits including better device monitoring, time and cost efficiency, improved quality of life, smart environmental control, and health monitoring
IoT applications span sectors relevant to home automation such as smart homes, smart cities, industrial automation, health monitoring, and environmental monitoring
This paper is a literature review synthesizing prior IoT home automation research, architectures, technologies, protocols, applications, benefits, and challenges
Combining artificial intelligence with IoT can further improve convenience and automation in daily life
Better device monitoring: IoT enables device-to-device transmission and remote management, removing the need for constant user intervention
Efficiency and time savings: IoT automation reduces repetitive user tasks and can yield more efficient and consistent results
Cost and energy savings: Optimal monitoring and control via IoT can reduce energy and resource waste, lowering costs
Smart environment and comfort: Preset programs can automate windows, shades, and HVAC control based on environmental inputs to regulate indoor conditions
Health monitoring: IoT devices can assist in tracking health metrics and supporting medical care, benefiting elderly and disabled users
Specific IoT technologies and protocols relevant to home automation include Bluetooth/BLE, ZigBee, Z-Wave, Wi-Fi, cellular, NFC, and LoRaWAN, each with tradeoffs in range, power, data rate, and cost
Ahmed ElShafee (2012) implemented a WiFi-based home automation prototype showing remote control and monitoring and claiming good scalability and flexibility
Vinay Sagar K (2015) demonstrated a low-cost, expandable IoT home automation system with successful remote appliance control over the internet

Reviews and surveys (Neha Malik 2017, Shaikh Amreen 2017, Anurag Tiwari et al. 2017, Satish Palaniappan 2015) document IoT home automation architectures, sensing-based monitoring, and highlight security and privacy challenges

Tradeoffs claim: Bluetooth and ZigBee offer low-power local links, Z-Wave targets home automation simplicity, Wi-Fi offers high throughput but higher power use, cellular supports long-range but higher cost, LoRaWAN supports low-power wide-area deployments, and NFC enables very short-range secure interactions
